questions.prompt: According to the opening, what must a single man with a fortune want?
questions.explanation: The famous opening states a single man in possession of a good fortune 'must be in want of a wife.'

questions.prompt: What is ironic about the phrase 'truth universally acknowledged'?

choices.text: It reflects the neighbors' assumptions, not actual truth

questions.explanation: Austen uses irony here; this 'truth' is really the assumption of matchmaking families, not a genuine universal fact.

questions.prompt: What does 'rightful property' suggest about how families viewed the bachelor?

choices.text: He was seen as a prize to be claimed for a daughter

questions.explanation: The phrase satirizes how families saw wealthy bachelors as belonging to their daughters by right.

questions.prompt: What news does Mrs. Bennet share with her husband?

choices.text: One of their daughters is engaged
They are moving to a new house

questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet excitedly tells Mr. Bennet that 'Netherfield Park is let at last.'

questions.prompt: What does Mr. Bennet's 'no answer' suggest about his character?

choices.text: He enjoys teasing his wife by being indifferent
He is genuinely uninterested in everything

questions.explanation: Mr. Bennet's deliberate silence is a form of dry teasing, knowing his wife will continue regardless.

questions.prompt: Who told Mrs. Bennet about Netherfield Park?
questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet says 'Mrs. Long has just been here, and she told me all about it.'

questions.prompt: What does Mr. Bennet mean by 'You want to tell me, and I have no objection'?

choices.text: He knows she'll tell him regardless, so he dryly consents
He is eager to hear the news

questions.explanation: Mr. Bennet uses understated humor, acknowledging she'll share the gossip whether he asks or not.

questions.prompt: What is a 'chaise and four'?

choices.text: A carriage drawn by four horses

questions.explanation: A chaise and four is a carriage pulled by four horses, indicating wealth and status.

questions.prompt: Where is the young man from?
questions.explanation: Mrs. Long says Netherfield is taken by 'a young man of large fortune from the north of England.'

questions.prompt: What is the young man's name?
questions.explanation: His name is revealed as 'Bingley.'

questions.prompt: Why does Mrs. Bennet consider Mr. Bingley 'a fine thing for our girls'?

choices.text: She sees him as a potential husband for one of her daughters
He will be a good neighbor

questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet explicitly states 'I am thinking of his marrying one of them.'

questions.prompt: How much is Mr. Bingley's annual income?

choices.text: One or two thousand a year
Four or five thousand a year

questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet exclaims he has 'four or five thousand a year.'

questions.prompt: Why does Mr. Bennet suggest Mrs. Bennet go herself to meet Bingley?

choices.text: He's playfully teasing her by implying Bingley might prefer her
He genuinely thinks she's the most attractive
He doesn't want to go alone

questions.explanation: Mr. Bennet uses dry humor, jokingly suggesting 'Mr. Bingley may like you the best of the party.'

questions.prompt: What does Mrs. Bennet want Mr. Bennet to do?

choices.text: Visit Mr. Bingley as soon as he arrives

questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet insists 'you must visit him as soon as he comes.'

questions.prompt: What does 'design' mean in 'Is that his design in settling here?'
questions.explanation: Mr. Bennet sarcastically asks if finding a wife is Bingley's plan ('design') in moving to the area.

questions.prompt: What does Mr. Bennet's comment about beauty really mean?

choices.text: He's slyly insulting Mrs. Bennet's looks

questions.explanation: His remark 'a woman has not often much beauty to think of' after five children is a subtle, sardonic jab.

questions.prompt: How many daughters do the Bennets have?
questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet mentions 'five grown-up daughters.'

questions.prompt: Does Mrs. Bennet take the compliment about her beauty seriously?

choices.text: Yes, she seems pleased by the flattery

questions.explanation: Mrs. Bennet responds 'you flatter me' and admits she has 'had my share of beauty,' seeming pleased.

questions.prompt: Why does Mrs. Bennet mention Sir William and Lady Lucas?

choices.text: To pressure Mr. Bennet by showing their neighbors will visit first

questions.explanation: She uses social pressure, noting the Lucases 'are determined to go' to visit Mr. Bingley.

questions.prompt: What does 'establishment' mean here?

choices.text: A wealthy marriage and secure social position

questions.explanation: In Regency-era context, 'establishment' means a marriage that provides financial security and social standing.

questions.prompt: Why would it be 'impossible' for the Bennets to visit if Mr. Bennet doesn't go first?

choices.text: Social etiquette required the gentleman of the house to make the first call

questions.explanation: Regency social customs dictated that the head of household must make the introductory visit first.

questions.prompt: How long have Mr. and Mrs. Bennet been married?
questions.explanation: The narrator refers to 'the experience of three-and-twenty years' of marriage.

questions.prompt: What does the narrator's description suggest about the Bennets' marriage?

choices.text: They are fundamentally mismatched in intellect and temperament
They rarely speak to each other

questions.explanation: Mr. Bennet's complex wit contrasts sharply with Mrs. Bennet's 'mean understanding,' showing a mismatch.

questions.prompt: What does 'mean understanding' describe?
questions.explanation: In this context, 'mean' means poor or inferior, describing Mrs. Bennet's limited intellectual capacity.
